latestVersion.restrictions: ICPSR obtained these data from the Human Population  Laboratory under the agreement that the data are for the sole use of  ICPSR and may not be sold or provided to third parties outside the  ICPSR membership, and that these data are not to be used for any  commercial purpose. Users are reminded that, per ICPSR Bylaws, data  and other materials provided by ICPSR are to be used solely for  statistical analysis and reporting of aggregated information, and not  for investigation of specific individuals or organizations. Each  member institution gives assurance that such uses of statistical data  will conform to widely accepted standards of practice and legal  restrictions that are intended to protect the confidentiality of research subjects.

fields.value: Alameda County [California] Health and Ways of Living Study, 1974 Panel

authorAffiliation.value: California Department of Health Services. Human Population Laboratory

dsDescriptionValue.value: These data constitute the second wave of a survey designed to study the influence of health practices and social relationships on the physical and mental health of a typical sample of the population. The first wave (HEALTH AND WAYS OF LIVING STUDY, 1965 PANEL [ALAMEDA COUNTY, CALIFORNIA] [ICPSR 6688]) collected information for 6,928 respondents (including approximately 500 women aged 65 years and older) on chronic health conditions, health behaviors, social involvements, and psychological characteristics. The 1974 questionnaire was sent to 6,246 living subjects who had responded in 1965, and were able to be located. A total of 4,864 individuals responded in 1974. Questions were asked on marital and life satisfaction, parenting, physical activities, employment, and childhood experiences. Demographic information on age, race, height, weight, education, income, and religion was also collected. Included with this dataset is a separate file (Part 2) containing mortality data for respondents who died between the 1965 and 1974 panels, and information on nonrespondents.

distributorName.value: Inter-university Consortium for Political and Social Research

distributorAffiliation.value: Institute for Social Research, University of Michigan

fields.value: A nine-year follow-up of the respondents to the 1965  survey, which consisted of a stratified random sample of Alameda  County households with noninstitutionalized residents aged 21 or older, or aged 16-21 and older if married.
